item.title: Microservice BS
item.description: In the last 5 years, “microservice architecture” has gone from cool buzzword to dangerous plague rife with misinformation, slipped deadlines, and unquestionably shittier end products. A misplaced need for microservices drives organizations down the path of blindly scattering the business domain over the network. Production errors that would’ve been caught at compile time now arrear at runtime. Feature velocity is exchanged for defects. Every production incident turns into a murder mystery with unhelpful stack traces.

item.title: About
item.description: Canadian-Iraqi software engineer & startup enthusiast based in Vancouver, Canada I’ve been developing software for nearly 15 years. Previously Lightspeed, SSENSE, Shopify, co-founder of nukern, LXRandCo, and now-defunct Infantry Online. Currently Software Engineering Manager at Amazon Web Services where I’m building a services marketplace called IQ to connect freelancers, consultants, and fractional CTOs with businesses of all sizes. After two failed ventures and one successful IPO of an omnichannel retailer, I’ve developed a deep expertise in the ecommerce, luxury retail, and payments industries.
